title: Serif Numerals
content:
Can anyone ID the numerals in [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019234217/http:/www.fabienbarral.com/02visualcom/anatolie/anatolie(c)fbarral.jpg) printed piece? They're beautiful.

Thanks,  
Matt
author: Maverick18x

comments.content: Hi Matt, I'm sure it is [Adobe Garamond's Old Style Numerals.](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019234217/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/adobe-garamond/small-caps-and-oldstyle-figures/)

I'm fairly sure - sorry Geoff - that it isn't Adobe Garamond. Although it's a close match to the printed piece, Adobe Garamond's upward-tilting top-stroke of the **5** , and the unclosed bowls of the **6** and the **9** rule it out.

It is, I think, Peter Baker's Garamond-esque freeware font for medievalists, [Junicode](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019234217/http:/junicode.sourceforge.net/), or its predecessor JuniusModern, from the [Old English Font Pack](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019234217/http:/www.faculty.virginia.edu/OldEnglish/index.html) (which had the old-style numerals in default position, rather than as an opentype option, as in Junicode).

[See this image of the relevant Junicode characters](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019234217/http:/img197.imageshack.us/img197/8528/picture2a.png).
